Given the risk of infection, systemic administration of vancomycin and levofloxacin is the most appropriate initial management, followed by a referral to an ophthalmologist for further evaluation and treatment. Ultrasound examination of the left eye may be helpful in assessing the extent of the injury, but is not the first step in management. Examination of the fundus with a tropicamide application may also be necessary, but should be done by an ophthalmologist. Placing an ocular pad onto the affected eye may be helpful in reducing pain and light sensitivity, but should not be used as the first step in management.

The presence of conjunctival hyperemia, peaked pupil, iridial asymmetry, hyphema, and vitreous hemorrhage suggests that the patient has intraocular bleeding and possibly a ruptured globe. Topical application of tropicamide for fundus examination and ocular pad placement can worsen the bleeding and aggravate the condition. Ultrasound examination can be useful in ruling out retinal detachment but is not the first step in acute management. Systemic administration of antibiotics is recommended to cover for possible infection resulting from the open wound. Vancomycin and levofloxacin provide broad-spectrum coverage for gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.
